oai_dc:dc.dc:title: French. Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 11 h
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 11 h. Newspaper clipping: Tennessee Awake.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Politics & government; Clippings; Scrapbooks; Women; Women's rights;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: L. Crozier French

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: For information on license and use fees and acquiring high-resolution image files, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8814. Please provide a brief description of the material.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tennessee Awake. Even Tennessee legislators have been aroused and our old, barbarous laws ate at last about to be cancelled. We mav hope that soon the wife will be allowed to manage her own property. That the widow will inherit the sums as the widower, that the mother will be made an equal guardian with the father of their children;that women will be recognized as an influence in our school system, so they may give their best help to remove the blot of illiteracy that so mars our reputation as a progressive common wealth. It certainly will not be long before the men of Tennessee will realize that in depriving the daughters of our state of their right to participate in the affairs of government which they are taxed to support, they are robbing them of rights guaranteed by the constitution of the United States. The dead have been awakened—shall I sleep ? The world's at war with tyrants— shall I crouch? The harvest's ripe—and shall I pause to reap? I slumber not—the thorn is in my couch. Each day a trumpet soundeth in my ear. It's echo's in my heart. —BYRON. — L. CROZIER FRENCH.
